Course Section: APSC_V 367-101 - Humanitarian Engineering: Politics and Practice

The course is available to any engineering student in Years 3-5.

Interested students, please register on the waitlist and submit an application to:  https://ubc.ca1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_1NvFi8K40UsLPdI. Applications will be accepted up until August 6, 2024. Students will be advised if their application is accepted and if so, will be registered in the course in August.

APSC 367 has been approved to cover the Impact of Engineering on Society, Sustainability and Environmental Stewardship requirement for all BASc students with the exception of CIVL and ENVE.

Course Section: ARTH_V 300-001 - Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History

Course Section Definition Public Notes: Painting, sculpture, and graphic art in France, the Netherlands, Germany, and England in the 15th and 16th centuries, with special emphasis on the major figures of this period, from van Eyck and van der Weyden to Grunewald, Bosch, Durer, Holbein, and Pieter Bruegel. Topics covered include the transformation of craft into art as a self-reflective and intellectual practice (Kunst); the emergence of oil painting as a transformative media; the German sculpted altarpiece and the triptych as Northern genres of art; visual culture and the Protestant Reformation; the emergence of graphic culture and the fine art print; witchcraft and mystical nature in German art; and the birth of secular art: portraiture, landscape, and scenes of everyday life.

This course tracks the major themes and practices in artistic production in early twentieth-century Europe and North America known collectively as “Modernism,” from the bold expressionism of the turn of the century to the stark minimalism of the 1960s. Situating visual and material cultural within the historical contexts of the two World Wars, the boom of consumer capitalism, and new forms of colonial expansion, our course will interrogate the definitions and limits of “modernism” and “modernity” within the history of art.

Course Section: ARTH_V 345-001 - History of Photography: Archive, Spectacle, Reality
Course Section Definition Public Notes: This lecture course considers the artistic, social, and political dimensions of photographic history, exploring creative practices, imperial agendas, scientific applications, social portraiture, documentary styles, self-fashioning, and activism. How do particular photographic practices shape our assumptions about reality, fiction, history, or memory? How do they perpetuate power dynamics or produce new forms of relationship and being-with-others? How are they naturalized or activated by storytelling?

“We live in a world of images,” says the Brethren of Purity, a group of Muslim philosophers from ninth-century Baghdad. This course takes its cue from there and explores the fascinating world of making, viewing, and experiencing images in the lands of Islam: from frescoes to portable objects, and from manuscript paintings to photography. We will see that unlike prevalent prejudices and assumptions, images were an integral part of life for people from all echelons of society across the Islamic world, and in remarkably diverse ways. Hence, the course challenges the misconception that Islamic Art was anti-image. Learn more on the ARTH 350 blog: https://blogs.ubc.ca/arth350/

This course traces the history of Early Modern through Postmodern art as the history of paradigm shifts in the technological mediation of the phenomenal world. We explore single- point perspective, often understood to be the crowning achievement of Western illusionistic pictorial construction, as it developed in dialogic relationship to mathematics, geometry and architecture. We then move through the heliocentric revolution that undergirds the Early Modern period and the new technologies of social organization that found the institutions of the 18th and 19th centuries, informing the Enlightenment era’s development of aesthetics. Finally, we explore the discourse of and relationship between medium and media that informs visual cognition and mediates social relations in the 20th century.
